title: Django for Everybody (DJ4E)
description: Hello and welcome to my site where you can work through these modules and learn develop Python / Django database-backed web applications.

modules.title: Introduction to Dynamic Web Content
modules.description: We look at the basic structure of a web application and how a web browser interacts with a web server.   We explore the Request-Response Cycle that is the basis of the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP).

videos.title: Web Applications and the Request/Response Cycle
Using Sockets to Make Network Connections in Python
Building a Simple Web Browser in Python
Building a Simple HTTP Server in Python

references.title: What Happens When You Click a Link? - Computerphile

modules.title: Installing Django on PythonAnywhere
modules.description: This walks through the installation steps for Django on PythonAnywhere.  If you cannot use PythonAnywhere, you can also install Django locally and submit assignments your local computer for grading.  Installing Django locally will be described in an upcoming lesson.

references.title: Writing your first Django app, part 1
Notes on Running Django Project Tutorials on PythonAnywhere
Setting up the django.org tutorial on PythonAnywhere
Quora: What web framework do you use in your company? Is it Django?

modules.title: Using the Command Line Shell on PythonAnywhere
modules.description: During this class you will be using the command line interface (shell) to work with Linux on PythonAnywhere.  Since Linux is the operating system used by most of the cloud servers in production, it is good for you to have a basic understanding of the Linux command line interface.  In this section we do a quick overview of using the Shell on PythonAnywhere. For this module you watch a video and take a quiz.

discussions.title: Using the Command Shell on PythonAnywhere

videos.title: Using the Command Line Shell on PythonAnywhere

lti.title: Quiz: Using the Linux Command Line

modules.title: HyperText Markup Language (HTML)
modules.description: We briefly cover the basics of the HyperText Markup Language (HTML) that is the markup for web pages.  The recorded lectures are from Web Applications for Everybody.

references.title: Notes on Running Django Project Tutorials on PythonAnywhere

modules.title: Cascading Style Sheets (CSS)
modules.description: We briefly cover the basics of cascading Style Sheets (CSS) that allow us to style the markup for web pages.

references.title: Web Developer Plugin by Chris Pedrick
CSS Cheat Sheet by Leslie Frank

json.title: Cascading Style Sheets
json.description: In this assignment you will develop a Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) to control, the look, feel, and layout of some provide HTML content.
json.grading: This is a relatively simple assignment.  Don't take off points for little mistakes.  If they seem to have done the assignment give them full credit.   Feel free to make suggestions if there are small mistakes.  Please keep your comments positive and useful.  If you do not take grading seriously, the instructors may delete your response and you will lose points.

parts.title: Image (JPG or PNG) of your index.htm with the styling applied
Please paste the source code of your blocks.css file
Image (JPG or PNG) of your blocks.css passing the W3 CSS validator
Image (JPG or PNG) of your browser viewing www.brainyquote.com with all styles turned off
Image (JPG or PNG) of your browser at www.brainyquote.com inspecting the navigation element to find its background color

modules.title: Basic SQL
modules.description: This is a quick look at databases in general and the basic operations (CRUD) in Structured Query Language (SQL). We don't go too far into SQL because we will be using Django's model capabilities to build the databases for our application.

references.title: Liz Fong: Creating the SQL Database Standards

modules.title: Django Data Models
modules.description: This section explores how we define models in Django and then we build the data models and explore the administration interface for our application.

videos.title: Data Model Migration in Django
videos.todo: Need to make migration fit better in DJ-02

videos.title: Demonstration: Resetting your Django database on PythonAnywhere

references.title: Writing your first Django app, part 2
Notes on Running Django Project Tutorials on PythonAnywhere

modules.title: Understanding Model View Controller (MVC)
modules.description: We cover the concept of the Model-View-Controller (MVC) in web applications.

references.title: Two MVC Approaches: Python/Django versus Java/Spring MVC

modules.title: Django Views and Templates
modules.description: We finally get to looking at the core of a Django application - the views and templates.

videos.title: Inside Django Views and HTML Escaping in Django

references.title: Writing your first Django app, part 3
Notes on Running Django Project Tutorials on PythonAnywhere

modules.title: Object-Oriented Programming in Python
modules.description: We do a quick look at how Python supports the Object-Oriented programming pattern.

references.title: Quora: Is C++ Object Oriented or Procedural?

modules.title: Django Generic Views
modules.description: We look at the generic views capability within Django.

references.title: Writing your first Django app, part 4
Django Documentation: Generic list display views
Django Documentation: Generic detail display views

modules.title: Forms in HTTP and HTML
modules.description: We cover how GET and POST work, how forms are constructed from HTML, how we protect our applications against Cross-Site Scripting Forgery (CSRF), and how we handle browser refreshes after POST.

videos.title: Forms and Cross Site Request Forgery (CSRF)

lti.title: Auto-grader: Django Tutorial part 4
lti.learning_objectives: Forms / CSRF / DB update / Generic Views

references.title: Writing your first Django app, part 4

modules.title: Cookies and Sessions
modules.description: We explore how cookies work in the browser and how to set and read cookies in Django.  We then explore how cookies are used to support sessions in Django and how we use sessions in Django.

modules.title: One-To-Many Data Models
modules.description: We explore the design of one-to-many data models.

videos.title: Storing Primary and Foreign Keys in a Database
Using the Django Shell to Explore One-to-Many Models
videos.notes: revised 2021-01 truncated reference to m-2-m at end formerly ZdLpAtfWfZk

videos.title: Loading One-to-Many Data using a Django Batch Script
videos.notes: Reused the first part of the many_load video - added a new ending cats_load

lti.title: Quiz: One to Many Data Models

json.title: Unesco Data Model
json.description: You will upload a picture of your normalized Unesco data model.  It can be a photo of a hand-drawn model or you can use a layout tool.  You should use 'Crow's Foot Notation' for your model and both ends of each line must be properly labelled with a 'one' or 'many' indication.
json.grading: This assignment is worth 10 points. 6 points come from your peers and 4 points come from you grading other student's submissions. Don't take off points for little mistakes.  If they seem to have done the assignment give them full credit.   Feel free to make suggestions if there are small mistakes.  Please keep your comments positive and useful.  If you do not take grading seriously, the instructors may delete your response and you will lose points.

parts.title: Image (JPG or PNG) of your Unesco data model (Maximum 2MB per file)

modules.title: Django Users and Authentication
modules.description: This exercise explores the interaction between authentication and our application.

videos.title: Creating and Managing Users in Django
Login and Logout URLs in Django

modules.title: Form Objects in Django
modules.description: We cover how to use the Django built in forms objects and their connection to Django models to futher simplify our view processing.

modules.title: Autos CRUD Application
modules.description: In this assignment we build a small CRUD application from scratch to support an autos database that we will use as a base to build on going forward.   This will serve as a way to review some of the concepts in the tutorial that we might have covered a little too quickly.

videos.title: Walkthrough of the DJ4E Autos Sample - Generic Edit Forms

modules.title: Cats CRUD Application
modules.description: This module will build a second CRUD application to make sure you know how to make new applications according to a specification.

modules.title: Putting Django Projects into GitHub (Optional)
modules.description: This exercise uploads your Django projects on PythonAnywhere to a private repository on GitHub if you have access to private repositories.  Please do not put your assignments in a public GitHub repository. Github provides free private repositories for small numbers of collaborators.

videos.title: Using GitHub with Django and PythonAnywhere

references.title: Unlimited Free Private Repositories on GitHub
Caching your GitHub password in Linux

modules.title: Installing Django locally (optional)
modules.description: This is an optional exercise to install Django locally to both speed your development cycles and to play with the sample code.  The next module inludes quite a bit of new code so you will be able to develop more quickly with Django installed locally.  You can submit your assignments from your local computer using a technology called 'ngrok'.

references.title: Using ngrok to submit a local application to the Autograder

modules.title: Owned Rows
modules.description: We cover how we mark objects as 'owned' by Django users.

videos.title: Owned Rows in Django - Generic Views Review

modules.title: Classified Ads #1
modules.description: We explore crispy forms, and bootstrap menus and then use owned rows we write the first iteration of the classified ads application.
modules.todo: How to switch Django to MySQL on PythonAnywhere

videos.title: Walking through the DJ4E Crispy Forms (crispy) Sample Code
Walking through the DJ4E My Articles (myarts) Sample Code
Walking through the DJ4E Bootstrap Menu (menu) Sample Code

modules.title: JavaScript
modules.description: We take a quick look at the JavaScript language and how it is used in the browser.

references.title: Bonus: Building JavaScript with with Brendan Eich

modules.title: Object Oriented Programming in JavaScript
modules.description: We do a quick look at how the JavaScript language supports the Object-Oriented pattern.

videos.title: Building Classes and Objects in JavaScript

references.title: Quora: Is C++ Object Oriented or Procedural?

modules.title: Classified Ads + Pictures
modules.description: We add pictures to our classified ads application.

videos.title: Walking through the DJ4E Pictures (pics) Sample Code

json.title: Menus and Pictures
json.description: In this assignment you will take some screen shots to deomstrate the look and feel of your application..
json.grading: This is a relatively simple assignment.  Don't take off points for little mistakes.  If they seem to have done the assignment give them full credit.   Feel free to make suggestions if there are small mistakes.  Please keep your comments positive and useful.  If you do not take grading seriously, the instructors may delete your response and you will lose points.

parts.title: Image (JPG or PNG) of a detail page showing a picture to the right of the Ad, edit and update buttons, and the top menu
Image (JPG or PNG) of an Ad detail page showing the picture maximized as an overlay

modules.title: Many-To-Many Data Models
modules.description: We further explore the design of many-to-many data models and write a Django script to load comma-separated (CSV) data into many-to-many tables.

videos.title: A Simple Many-To-Many Example in Django
Many-To-Many Data Models for Courses and Membership
Building a Django Batch Script to Load Data from CSV

modules.title: Classified Ads + Comments
modules.description: We add comments to our classified ads application.

videos.title: Walking through the DJ4E Forums (forums) Sample Code

modules.title: jQuery
modules.description: This is a brief introduction to the jQuery library which is widely used to do in-browser manipulation of the Document Object Model(DOM) and event handling.

videos.title: jQuery and the Document Object Model
Walking through the DJ4E jQuery DOM sample code
Walking through the DJ4E jQuery setup sample code
Walking through the DJ4E jQuery events sample code
Walking through the DJ4E jQuery DOM modification sample code

modules.title: JSON / AJAX
modules.description: In this section we look at JavaScript Object Notation (JSON).  JSON is commonly used as a syntax to exchange data between code running on the server (i.e. in Django) and code running in the browser (JavaScript/jQuery).

videos.title: Walking through the DJ4E JSON Sample Code
Building an AJAX Chat with Django
Walking through the DJ4E JSON (chat) Sample Code

modules.title: Classified Ads #3
modules.description: We add favorites to our classified ads application.

json.description: This is an assignment to make sure that your user interface properly supports the stars in the favorites.

modules.title: Building an Application on Your Own
modules.description: This week - in the auto grader - you will be presented with a sample application and you are to replicate its fuctionality.  There is no new material - but you might want to look back and review some material to help with this assignment.

lti.title: Auto-grader: An Application of Your Own

modules.title: CRUD Practice
modules.description: Some CRUD Exercises.

modules.title: Project Overview
modules.description: Introduce your project to the rest of the class.

json.title: Milestone 1: Describe Your Project
json.description: Please describe your proposed Django database-backed web site project in 1-2 paragraphs.   Talk about the scope of the project, similar web sites, the kind of data the project will store and show and the interactive elements that get data from logged-in end users.
json.grading: This assignment is worth 10 points. 6 points come from your peers and 4 points come from you grading other student's submissions. Don't take off points for little mistakes.  If they seem to have done the assignment give them full credit.   Feel free to make suggestions if there are small mistakes.  Please keep your comments positive and useful.  If you do not take grading seriously, the instructors may delete your response and you will lose points.

parts.title: URL of your GitHub Repo - If it is private just put in your github account url and mention that your repo is private below
Please describe your project in a few paragraphs.

modules.title: Project Milestone 2
modules.description: Introduce your project to the rest of the class.

json.title: Milestone 2: Revise your Project Description
json.description: For this milestone, you will revise your 1-2 paragraph summary of your project idea and add a short paragraph describing what the changes are and why you are making the changes.  If you are not making any changes briefly describe anything you have learned or improved on your description.
json.grading: This assignment is worth 10 points. 6 points come from your peers and 4 points come from you grading other student's submissions. Don't take off points for little mistakes.  If they seem to have done the assignment give them full credit.   Feel free to make suggestions if there are small mistakes.  Please keep your comments positive and useful.  If you do not take grading seriously, the instructors may delete your response and you will lose points.

parts.title: URL of your GitHub Repo - If it is private just put in your github account url and mention that your repo is private below
Please describe your project (again) in a few paragraphs.

modules.title: Project Milestone 3
modules.description: Design a first verson of the user interface (UI) for your project.

json.title: Milestone 3: User Interface Brainstorm
json.description: For this milestone, you will begin to develop the user interface for your project. Like in previous milestones, you will get a chance to revise your UI design and can still change it quite dramatically with no negative consequences.
json.grading: This assignment is worth 10 points. 6 points come from your peers and 4 points come from you grading other student's submissions. Don't take off points for little mistakes.  If they seem to have done the assignment give them full credit.   Feel free to make suggestions if there are small mistakes.  Please keep your comments positive and useful.  If you do not take grading seriously, the instructors may delete your response and you will lose points.

parts.title: URL of your GitHub Repo - If it is private just put in your github account url and mention that your repo is private below

modules.title: Project Milestone 4
modules.description: Design a first verson of the data model (UI) for your project.

json.title: Milestone 4: Data Model
json.description: For this milestone, you will begin to develop the data model for your project. Like in previous milestones, you will get a chance to revise your model and change it with no negative consequences.  You are likely to get valuable feedback on your submission from others that will help improve your model.
json.grading: This assignment is worth 10 points. 6 points come from your peers and 4 points come from you grading other student's submissions. Don't take off points for little mistakes.  If they seem to have done the assignment give them full credit.   Feel free to make suggestions if there are small mistakes.  Please keep your comments positive and useful.  If you do not take grading seriously, the instructors may delete your response and you will lose points.

parts.title: URL of your GitHub Repo - If it is private just put in your github account url and mention that your repo is private below

Data Model Image
The models.py file for your model.  Does not have to be complete and syntax errors are OK.  Focus on important conceptual things like foreign keys.

modules.title: Project Milestone 5 - Project Review
modules.description: This is a project review to get feedback to help you for the final project submission.

json.title: Milestone 5: Project Review
json.description: For this milestone you will submit a description of your project, a URL, some screen shots, and optionally an account / password if needed so we can review your project work to date.  You will continue to work on and improve your project, taking the comments from this preer review as input to your work.   There will be a second and final review after this review.
json.grading: This assignment is worth 10 points. 4 points come from your peers and 4 points come from you grading other student's submissions. Don't take off points for little mistakes.  If they seem to have done the assignment give them full credit.   Feel free to make suggestions if there are small mistakes.  Please keep your comments positive and useful.  If you do not take grading seriously, the instructors may delete your response and you will lose points.

parts.title: URL of your working web site.

A second representative screen shot of your application

modules.title: Project Milestone 6 - Final Report
modules.description: This is the final project submission.

modules.title: MDN Tutorial (Legacy)
modules.description: This is a set of assignments centered around the Mozilla Developer Network Django tutorial.
